evidence_span: The sheaths of failed elements were heavily hydrided

source_id: STP1295-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_11th Volume_004_chunk2

source_id: STP1295-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_11th Volume_004_chunk2

source_id: STP1295-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_11th Volume_004_chunk2
evidence_span: In-reactor measurement of the gas pressure in a modified element to demonstrate no appreciable pressure rise due to the formation of carbon oxides

source_id: STP1295-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_11th Volume_004_chunk2
evidence_span: stress-corrosion cracking seems a simple explanation of the failures, with stress concentrations over the fuel cracks providing high local stresses and iodine providing the corrosive agent

source_id: STP1295-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_11th Volume_004_chunk2
evidence_span: The role of the graphite may be twofold. Those researchers backing mechanical causes proposed the graphite as a lubricant to reduce the stress concentrations, while those backing chemical causes proposed it for its known adsorption of iodine

source_id: STP1295-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_11th Volume_004_chunk2
evidence_span: fractographic evidence suggested that while both roles contribute, the chemical one predominates

source_id: STP1295-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_11th Volume_004_chunk5
evidence_span: Zircaloy-2 and -4, developed mainly in the United States, have been used in Germany for fuel rod claddings and in-core structural components from the beginning of reactor technology.

source_id: STP1295-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_11th Volume_004_chunk5
evidence_span: Zircaloy-2 and -4, developed mainly in the United States, have been used in Germany for fuel rod claddings and in-core structural components from the beginning of reactor technology.

source_id: STP1295-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_11th Volume_004_chunk5
evidence_span: Extensive studies of the material properties of the Zircaloys have been performed in Siemens laboratories since 1957. Irradiation testing was done in several test reactors.

source_id: STP1295-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_11th Volume_004_chunk5
evidence_span: However, the combined effects of irradiation and real environmental conditions were determined through many experimental irradiations in existing power reactors.

source_id: STP1295-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_11th Volume_004_chunk5
evidence_span: Elaborate examinations in the reactor pools of such experimental materials and of many standard fuel rods and assemblies after intermediate, full, and intentionally extended exposures were the main source of information and hard data.

source_id: STP1295-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_11th Volume_004_chunk5
evidence_span: Zircaloy-2 and -4 turned out to be very reliable materials that fulfilled all requirements for normal operation and likewise the requirements for postulated accidental conditions and for intermediate storage for many years.

conditions.condition_type: normal operation, postulated accidental conditions, intermediate storage

evidence_span: BWRs and PWRs need differently optimized materials.

source_id: STP1295-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_11th Volume_004_chunk5
evidence_span: Today's more demanding operation conditions and discharge burnups required a further optimization of the Zircaloys and for "hot' PWRs even the development of more corrosion-resistant Zr alloys.
value: more corrosion-resistant alloys needed for hot PWRs

source_id: STP1295-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_11th Volume_004_chunk5
evidence_span: A significant improvement of PWR corrosion behavior can be achieved with Zr alloys using the alloying elements of Zircaloy with somewhat modified concentrations.
composition_raw: alloying elements of Zircaloy with somewhat modified concentrations

source_id: STP1295-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_11th Volume_004_chunk5
evidence_span: Sn should be below or at least in the lower range of the ASTM specification range for Zircaloy-4, Fe and Cr should be somewhat higher, and Si should be specified as an alloying element rather than as an impurity.
composition_raw: Sn below or lower range of ASTM spec, Fe higher, Cr higher, Si as alloying element

source_id: STP1295-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_11th Volume_004_chunk5
evidence_span: The low-alloyed Zirconium-base alloys Zircaloy-2 and -4 were developed for fuel rod claddings and for fuel assembly and other in-core structural components in the late 1950s and early 1960s, mainly in the United States (Bettis Atomic Power Laboratories) [1].
specimen_state: fuel rod cladding, fuel assembly, in-core structural component

source_id: STP1295-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_11th Volume_004_chunk5
evidence_span: The incentives came not only from the outstanding high neutron transparency of zirconium (after purification from the high cross-section hafnium companion in the natural ores) but also from the fact that the austenitic stainless steels suffered from irradiation-assisted stress corrosion cracking in LWR environments.

source_id: STP1295-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_11th Volume_004_chunk5
evidence_span: Zirconium alloys formed from the early beginning a sound basis for any heavy water/natural or low-enriched uranium power reactor strategy, being quite superior to aluminum alloys.

conditions.reactor_type: heavy water/natural or low-enriched uranium power reactor
